issues.text: Whether the prosecution has established that Mahabir caused the death of Indira by murder

anchor.surface_text: In appeal in this Court Mr. Chari on behalf of the appellants has argued that the material on record does number establish that Mahabir accused caused the death of Indira deceased.

issues.text: Whether the death of Indira was homicidal and not natural

anchor.surface_text: In any case, according to the learned counsel, it has number been proved that the death of Indira was homicidal and number natural.

issues.text: Whether Dasrath was present at his house in Jamalpur on the night of occurrence

anchor.surface_text: So far as Dasrath accused is concerned, the submission made is that there is numbercogent evidence on the record to show that he was present at his house in Jamalpur on the night of occurrence.

issues.text: Whether Kasim took part in the removal of the dead body of Indira

anchor.surface_text: As regards Kasim accused, the counsel contends that he is number proved to have taken part in the removal of the dead body of Indira from the house of Mahabir.

issues.text: Whether Mahadeo knew that Indira had been murdered

anchor.surface_text: In respect of Mahadeo, the argument is that he did number know that Indira had been murdered.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution has been able to establish the charges against the accused and if so against which of them

anchor.surface_text: We have heard the arguments at length and shall number proceed to examine as to whether the prosecution has been able to establish the charge against the accused and if so, against which of them.

anchor.surface_text: The above circumstances, in our opinion, clearly point to the conclusion that Mahabir accused was responsible for the death of Indira. It is n

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chain of circumstances including motive, threat, suspicious disposal of body, post-mortem findings consistent with poisoning, no direct evidence needed.

holdings.text: The circumstances of the present case taken in their entirety clearly point to the conclusion that the death of Indira was not natural but was due to foul-play.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances of the present case taken in their entirety clearly point to the conclusion that the death of Indira was not natural but was

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-mortem congestion of organs indicative of poisoning despite no detection; cites medical texts and precedents like Anant Chintaman Lagu on circumstantial proof in poisoning cases.

holdings.text: There is no reliable evidence to show that Dasrath was present in the house on the night in question.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution witnesses unreliable due to relationship and litigation; confessional statement rules out presence; absence from hostel not conclusive.

holdings.text: We find that there is no reliable evidence as may show that Kasim was present at the house of Mahabir on the night of occurrence and took part in the disposal of the dead body of Indira.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Police statements inadmissible under s162 CrPC.

holdings.text: The circumstances in which the death of Indira took place and the surreptitious manner in which her dead body was removed at dead of night from Mahabir's house to Kamarganj Ghat go to show that Mahadeo was not unaware of the fact that Indira's death was not natural and had been brought about by Mahabir.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances in which the death of Indira took place and the surreptitious manner in which her dead body was removed at dead of night

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission of participation in disposal; context of stealthy nighttime removal indicates knowledge of unnatural death.

holdings.text: We, therefore, are of the opinion that no case has been proved against Dasrath and Kasim accused.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of reliable evidence linking them to crimes.

holdings.text: Such statements are legally not admissible in evidence and cannot be used as substantive evidence. According to section 162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure... As such, the aforesaid statements must be excluded from consideration.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s162 CrPC bars use of police statements as substantive evidence, applies to accused too; cites Narayan Swami v. Emperor; no s27 discovery; not s32 dying decl.

holdings.text: As both Dasrath and Kasim are being acquitted, the charge under section 120B Indian Penal Code against Mahabir for conspiracy with Dasrath to murder Indira and against Mahadeo for conspiracy with Kasim for causing disappearance of dead body of Indira must fail.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquittal of co-conspirators necessitates failure of conspiracy charge.

holdings.text: The conviction of Mahabir for offences under sections 302 and 201 Indian Penal Code as well as the sentence on that score is maintained. Likewise, the conviction and sentence of Mahadeo for offence under section 201 Indian Penal Code is maintained.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution proved charges against Mahabir (murder and disposal) and Mahadeo (disposal).

precedents.citation: Anant Chintaman Lagu v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference in this context may be made to the following observations of Hidayatullah J.  as he then was  who spoke for the majority in the case of Anant Chintaman Lagu v. The State of Bombay 1  A case of murder by administration of poison is almost always one of secrecy. The poisoner seldom takes another into his confidence, and his preparations to the commission of the offence are also secret. He watches his opportunity and administers the poison in a manner calculated to avoid its detection. The greater his knowledge of poisons, the greater the secrecy, and consequently the greater the difficulty of proving the case against him.

precedents.case_name: Anant Chintaman Lagu v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: In cases of murder by poisoning, circumstantial evidence can establish guilt even without isolation and detection of the poison, provided the circumstances are decisive.
precedents.cited_holding: But if circumstantial evidence, in the absence of direct proof of the three elements, is so decisive that the Court can unhesitatingly hold that death was a result of administration of poison though not detected and that the poison must have been administered by the accused person, then the conviction can be rested on it.

precedents.citation: State Government, Madhya Pradesh v. Ramkrishna Ganpatrao Limsey and Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made by Mr. Chari to the case of State Government, Madhya Pradesh v. Ramkrishna Ganpatrao Limsey and Ors.  1  wherein this Court dealt with an appeal against acquittal and observed that the exercise of extraordinary jurisdiction under Article 136 of the Constitution is not justifiable in criminal cases unless exceptional and special circumstances are shown to exist or that substantial and grave injustice has been done.

precedents.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Ramkrishna Ganpatrao Limsey
precedents.cited_proposition: Extraordinary jurisdiction under Article 136 should not be exercised in criminal cases against acquittal unless exceptional circumstances or grave injustice shown.

anchor.surface_text: see Narayan Swami v. Emperor,  1 . Lord Atkin, in that case, while dealing with section 162 of the, Code of Criminal Procedure, observed Then follows the Section in question which is drawn in the same general way relating to any person. That

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 162 CrPC applies not only to witnesses but also to statements made by accused persons to police during investigation.
precedents.cited_holding: the words in their ordinary meaning would include any person though he may thereafter be accused seems plain.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal of Dasrath and Kasim allowed; their convictions set aside and acquitted. Convictions of Mahabir and Mahadeo under section 120B IPC set aside. Conviction of Mahabir under sections 302 read with 34 and 201 IPC and sentence maintained. Conviction and sentence of Mahadeo under section 201 IPC maintained.
